stem:
A patient with a T6 spinal cord injury is exhibiting signs of autonomic dysreflexia. Based on the assessment findings, prioritize the following interventions in the order they should be implemented.

1. Immediately [cloze-1] the patient's blood pressure.
2. Then, [cloze-2] the patient to a sitting position.
3. Next, assess for and [cloze-3] the cause of the autonomic dysreflexia.
4. Finally, administer [cloze-4] medication as prescribed if the blood pressure remains elevated after addressing the cause.

itemContext.sbar: S: Jameson Reynolds, 42-year-old male with a T6 spinal cord injury, admitted 3 days ago for rehabilitation following a motor vehicle accident. B: Mr. Reynolds has been stable since admission. This morning, he reported a sudden onset of severe headache and blurred vision. A: At 0700, assessment revealed a significantly elevated blood pressure of 210/110 mmHg and a decreased heart rate of 52 bpm. He also presents with a flushed face and diaphoresis above the level of his injury. He denies bladder distention but reports feeling constipated. The patient is alert and oriented but anxious due to the sudden onset of symptoms. O: STAT! The patient is suspected of experiencing autonomic dysreflexia, a potentially life-threatening condition. Immediate orders are requested for blood pressure management and further intervention to identify and address the underlying cause. Prepare to administer PRN hydralazine as per protocol. Physician notified at 0705 and verbal orders received and transcribed. Continuous blood pressure monitoring initiated.

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content: 0600: BP 120/80 mmHg, HR 70 bpm, RR 16, SpO2 98%; 0700: BP 210/110 mmHg, HR 52 bpm, RR 18, SpO2 99%

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: CBC: WNL; BMP: WNL; UA: WNL

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Hydralazine 20mg IV PRN for SBP > 180 mmHg; Docusate sodium 100mg PO daily; Bisacodyl suppository PRN for constipation

topicTags: Neurological: Spinal Cord Injury & Autonomic Dysreflexia

rationale.correct: Autonomic dysreflexia is a medical emergency requiring immediate intervention. The priority is to lower the blood pressure to prevent stroke or other complications. Elevated blood pressure should be addressed before other interventions. Raising the head of the bed to a sitting position helps to lower blood pressure by promoting venous pooling. Identifying and removing the noxious stimulus is the next crucial step. Common causes include bladder distention, bowel impaction, or skin irritation. Medication should only be administered if non-pharmacological interventions are insufficient to control the blood pressure.
rationale.incorrect: Delaying blood pressure monitoring or elevation of the patient's head could lead to a hypertensive crisis. Addressing the cause of the autonomic dysreflexia is important, but only after addressing the hypertension. Administering medication before attempting to identify and remove the cause may mask the underlying problem and lead to unnecessary medication use or complications.
clinicalPearls: Autonomic dysreflexia can occur at any time after spinal shock subsides.
Patient education is key to preventing autonomic dysreflexia. Teach patients to recognize the symptoms and take preventative measures.
Always suspect autonomic dysreflexia in patients with spinal cord injuries above T6 who present with sudden hypertension and headache.

questionTrap.trap: Some might prioritize finding the cause before monitoring the blood pressure, thinking that addressing the root issue will resolve the problem faster. However, the immediate danger is the severe hypertension.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember your ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation). In autonomic dysreflexia, circulation (specifically blood pressure) is the most immediate threat and must be addressed first.

mnemonic.title: SIT UP
mnemonic.expansion: Sit patient up; Investigate cause; Treat blood pressure; Use medication if needed; Prevent recurrence
